modules.preparagraph: Any method which takes a single parameter can be used as an infix operator: `a.m(b)` can be written `a m b`.
modules.code:
val g: Int = 3
(g + 4) should be(__) // + is an infix operator
g.+(4) should be(__) // same result but not using the infix operator

modules.preparagraph: Infix Operators do NOT work if an object has a method that takes two parameters:
modules.code:
val g: String = "Check out the big brains on Brad!"

g indexOf 'o' should be(__) //indexOf(Char) can be used as an infix operator

// g indexOf 'o', 4 should be (6) //indexOf(Char, Int) cannot be used an infix operator

g.indexOf('o', 7) should be(__) //indexOf(Char, Int) must use standard java/scala calls

modules.preparagraph:
Any method which does not require a parameter can be used as a postfix operator: `a.m` can be written `a m`.

For instance `a.##(b)` can be written `a ## b` and `a.!` can be written `a!``

**Postfix operators** have lower precedence than **infix operators**, so:
- `foo bar baz` means `foo.bar(baz)`.
- `foo bar baz bam` means `(foo.bar(baz)).bam`
- `foo bar baz bam bim` means `(foo.bar(baz)).bam(bim)`.
Prefix operators work if an object has a method name that starts with `unary_` :
Here we create our own prefix operator for our own class. The only identifiers that can be used as prefix operators are `+`, `-`, `!`, and `~`:
modules.code:
class Stereo {
  def unary_+ = "on"

  def unary_- = "off"
}

val stereo = new Stereo
(+stereo) should be(__)
(-stereo) should be(__)
